prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the person (let's call them "he") and his girlfriend live together. He pays all the rent and bills because she only works part-time. Then there's this incident where he left his wallet and asked her to pay for the takeout, which was under $40. She had a bad reaction, maybe even offended. Now he's considering making her pay some bills because of that one incident.

First, I need to think about the dynamics of their living arrangement. He's been paying everything up until now. Maybe he didn't have a problem with it before because they had an understanding, but this event changed his mind. The key points here are: he's the one paying all the bills, she's part-time, the takeout was $40, and her reaction was negative.

Is it fair to make her pay some bills because of this one incident? Well, if she's only working part-time and maybe her income is low, expecting her to take on a share of the bills might be a problem if she can't afford it. But the author is talking about "principal," meaning he wants her to start contributing in principle, even if it's not a lot. The question is whether making her pay over a single event is justified.

Her reaction might be due to feeling like she's being asked to take on a responsibility that wasn't part of their previous agreement. If he's been paying everything before, she might not be used to contributing. But the incident is small—$40. Maybe she was upset because it felt like a sudden change in expectations without prior discussion. The author might have been abrupt in making her pay it, which could have triggered her bad attitude.

Also, the way he phrased it—telling her she "had to get it"—might come across as demanding. Maybe he should have considered her perspective first. She might be struggling financially or not expect to have to cover expenses, especially if she's been in a position where he handled everything. A single incident doesn't necessarily mean she's unwilling to contribute, but it could indicate a communication issue.

On the other hand, the author is right that if she's living with him, contributing to some expenses is fair, especially if her income allows. But making her do it immediately after one incident without discussing it could be seen as taking it personally. The problem might not be the $40 but the fact that he's using this as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement without considering the bigger picture of their relationship and her financial situation.

So, is he in the wrong? It depends on the context. If there was no prior discussion about splitting expenses and he just decided to make her pay because of this one event, then maybe he's being unfair. Relationships require communication, and changing financial responsibilities on a whim without talking could lead to resentment. But if the underlying issue is that he feels she should contribute and this was the straw that broke the camel's back, then it's a matter of whether the approach was right.

The author's frustration is understandable, but using a single incident to demand a change in financial contributions without considering her ability to pay or discussing it calmly might be the wrong approach. The question is about whether he's in the wrong in making her start paying some bills because of this. The answer could be A or B depending on perspective. But since the incident was minor and the reaction disproportionate, maybe the author is in the wrong for overreacting and not communicating properly. Alternatively, if the author is just setting a boundary based on fairness, then maybe not. I think the key is the approach and the reason. The author is focusing on a principle of contribution, but the way he's handling it might be the issue. So maybe the answer is A (yes, he's in the wrong) because he's using a minor event to enforce a new rule without proper discussion, possibly without considering her financial situation. But I'm not entirely sure. Another angle is that he's right to expect some contribution, even if it's small, and the incident was a valid reason to bring up the conversation. But the problem is how he's handling it. The question is whether he's in the wrong. So, the answer is A if the approach was wrong, B if it's justified. I think the answer is A because he's being abrupt and using a minor issue to enforce a change without considering her situation and the relationship's context.
